author: Sophie Curtis
title: Premier League calls time on football fans using Kodi boxes to stream matches for free
text:
Technology Premier League calls time on football fans using Kodi boxes to stream matches for free Anyone who uses Kodi to watch premier League football matches without paying a subscription to Sky or BT is in for a nasty shock Share Man watching football on television (Photo: Getty) Share Get daily   Thank you for subscribing!   
Football fans who use Kodi boxes to watch Premier League matches for free are about to get a rude awakening. 
The Premier League has secured a court order that allows it to shut down illegal video streams of matches on Kodi, by blocking access to the computer servers used to power the streams. 
In the past, it was only able to shut down the streams themselves, which were relatively easy for pirate channels to re-establish. 
A Premier League spokesman said the ruling would allow it to target pirates in a more "precise manner". 
"For the first time this will enable the Premier League to disrupt and prevent the illegal streaming of our matches via IPTV, so-called Kodi, boxes," he said. 
Kodi boxes are one of the most popular ways to watch pirated video content in the UK. 
According to a recent survey commissioned by the security firm Irdeto, one in ten Brits who admit to watching pirated content say they use a Kodi box to do so. 
Although Kodi boxes are not illegal, many of these Kodi devices come pre-loaded with third party plug-ins and add-ons that allow users to stream pirated content to their TV. (Photo: PA / Gazette Live) 
The Federation Against Copyright Theft (FACT) recently launched a crackdown on the sale and distribution of these illegal "fully loaded" devices. 
Five people were arrested in the North West of England and Wales last month, charged with breaching the Copyright, Designs and Patent Act 1988, and one seller has been ordered to pay a fine of Â£250,000. 
"Set-top boxes loaded with apps and add-ons allowing access to copyright infringing material are very much illegal and anyone involved in selling these boxes should not be surprised to receive a knock on the door," said Kieron Sharp, Director General of FACT. (Photo: Gazette Live) 
Interestingly, Irdeto's research revealed that live sports was not the most popular type of pirated video content on Kodi - with movies and TV series topping of the list. 
The only countries that indicated that live sports was the type of pirated video content they were most interested in were Portugal (25%), Egypt (23%) and the Gulf Cooperation Council (19%). 
More men in each country indicated that live sports is the type of content they are most interested in pirating, while a majority of women prefer to pirate TV series. Like us on Facebook
